T1003.002::[Dragonfly] has dropped and executed SecretsDump to dump password hashes.
T1003.003::[Dragonfly] has dropped and executed SecretsDump to dump password hashes. They also obtained ntds.dit from domain controllers.
T1003.004::[Dragonfly] has dropped and executed SecretsDump to dump password hashes.
T1021.001::[Dragonfly] has moved laterally via RDP.
T1053.005::[Dragonfly] has used scheduled tasks to automatically log out of created accounts every 8 hours as well as to execute malicious files.
T1059.001::[Dragonfly] has used PowerShell scripts for execution.
T1059.003::[Dragonfly] has used various types of scripting to perform operations, including batch scripts.
T1059.006::[Dragonfly] has used various types of scripting to perform operations, including Python scripts. The group was observed installing Python 2.7 on a victim.
T1069.002::[Dragonfly] has used batch scripts to enumerate administrators and users in the domain.

T1070.001::[Dragonfly] has cleared Windows event logs and other logs produced by tools they used, including system, security, terminal services, remote services, and audit logs. The actors also deleted specific Registry keys.
T1070.004::[Dragonfly] has deleted many of its files used during operations as part of cleanup, including removing applications and deleting screenshots.
T1074.001::[Dragonfly] has created a directory named "out" in the user's %AppData% folder and copied files to it.
T1087.002::[Dragonfly] has used batch scripts to enumerate users on a victim domain controller.
T1110.002::[Dragonfly] has dropped and executed tools used for password cracking, including Hydra and [CrackMapExec].
T1114.002::[Dragonfly] has accessed email accounts using Outlook Web Access.
T1136.001::[Dragonfly] has created accounts on victims, including administrator accounts, some of which appeared to be tailored to each individual staging target.
T1195.002::[Dragonfly] has placed trojanized installers for control system software on legitimate vendor app stores.
T1204.002::[Dragonfly] has used various forms of spearphishing in attempts to get users to open malicious attachments.

T1505.003::[Dragonfly] has commonly created Web shells on victims' publicly accessible email and web servers, which they used to maintain access to a victim network and download additional malicious files.
T1547.001::[Dragonfly] has added the registry value ntdll to the Registry Run key to establish persistence.
T1562.004::[Dragonfly] has disabled host-based firewalls. The group has also globally opened port 3389.
T1564.002::[Dragonfly] has modified the Registry to hide created user accounts.
T1566.001::[Dragonfly] has sent emails with malicious attachments to gain initial access.
T1583.001::[Dragonfly] has registered domains for targeting intended victims.
T1583.003::[Dragonfly] has acquired VPS infrastructure for use in malicious campaigns.
T1584.004::[Dragonfly] has compromised legitimate websites to host C2 and malware modules.
T1588.002::[Dragonfly] has obtained and used tools such as [Mimikatz], [CrackMapExec], and [PsExec].
T1591.002::[Dragonfly] has collected open source information to identify relationships between organizations for targeting purposes.
T1595.002::[Dragonfly] has scanned targeted systems for vulnerable Citrix and Microsoft Exchange services.
T1598.002::[Dragonfly] has used spearphishing with Microsoft Office attachments to enable harvesting of user credentials.
T1598.003::[Dragonfly] has used spearphishing with PDF attachments containing malicious links that redirected to credential harvesting websites.
T1608.004::[Dragonfly] has compromised websites to redirect traffic and to host exploit kits.
